DOCNAME: CASE OF STEC AND OTHERS v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 14+P1-1;Not necessary to examine victim status of third, fourth and fifth applicants

CARDINAL . Reduced Earnings Allowance ( REA ) is an earnings - related additional benefit under the statutory occupational accident and disease scheme which was put in place in DATE . Originally the benefit was known as Special Hardship Allowance , but it was recast and renamed by LAW DATE . At the time of the introduction of these applications , the relevant legislation was Part V of ORG DATE .

CARDINAL . REA has , since DATE , been funded by general taxation rather than the ORG scheme . It is payable to employees or former employees who have suffered an accident at work or an occupational disease , with the purpose of compensating for an impairment in earning capacity . The DATE amount is based on a comparison between the claimant ’s earnings prior to the accident or disease and those in any actual or notional alternative employment still considered suitable despite the disability , subject to a maximum DATE award of GBP DATE . It is a non - contributory benefit , in that eligibility is not conditional on any or a certain number of contributions having been made to ORG .

CARDINAL . Under more recent legislation the benefit is being phased out altogether and no fresh right to REA can arise from an accident incurred or a disease contracted on or after DATE . In addition , a succession of legislative measures after DATE attempted to remove or reduce it for claimants no longer of working age , in respect of whom the government considered any comparison of “ earnings ” to be artificial . Before these changes , there had been a continued right to REA notwithstanding the attainment of retirement age and ORG had been payable concurrently with the ORG pension .

CARDINAL . The method chosen to reduce eligibility was to impose cut - off or limiting conditions by reference to the ages used by the statutory old - age pension scheme , namely CARDINAL for men and CARDINAL for women until DATE , then tapering up to eventual equality at CARDINAL in DATE ( Part II of ORG DATE , as amended by LAW DATE see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) .

All other ORG recipients would cease to receive ORG , and would instead receive ORG ( GPE ) either on reaching ( a ) CARDINAL , if a man , or DATE , if a woman , or ( b ) the date of retirement fixed by a notice , at DATE + for a man or CARDINAL + for a woman or on giving up employment at CARDINAL for a man or CARDINAL for a woman .

NORP State retirement pensions are funded entirely from ORG , to which all employers and the majority of the working population , whether employed or self - employed , are liable to pay compulsory contributions . The individual ’s liability for such contributions ceases at “ pensionable age ” .

CARDINAL . Men and women born before DATE attain pensionable age at DATE and CARDINAL respectively ( Schedule CARDINAL to LAW DATE ) . The present pension age for women was introduced in DATE by ORG . Prior to that , State pension age was DATE for both men and women . According to the government ’s Green and White Papers entitled respectively “ Options for Equality in State Pension Age ” ( Cm DATE , DATE ) and “ ORG ( ORG , DATE ) , the lower age for women was introduced in response to a campaign by unmarried women , many of whom spent much of their lives caring for dependent relatives , and also as part of a package to enable married couples , where the wife was usually younger than the husband and financially dependent on him , to receive a pension at the couples’ rate when the husband reached CARDINAL .

Moreover , a home responsibilities provision , introduced in DATE , now helped those whose working life was shortened because of time spent caring for a child or sick or disabled person to build up entitlement to a basic pension , and the concession which allowed married women to pay reduced - rate ORG contributions , leaving them dependent on their husbands’ contributions , was withdrawn in DATE . LAW DATE had amended LAW DATE to make it unlawful for an employer to have different retirement ages for men and women . The view of the government , expressed in the White Paper , was that the preferential pension age for women had no place in modern society and it was proposed to equalise pensionable age for men and women .

CARDINAL . It was decided to introduce the change gradually to ensure that women affected by the change and their employers had ample time to adjust their expectations and arrange their financial affairs accordingly .

CARDINAL . Council Directive CARDINAL/CARDINAL/EEC of DATE ( “ the Directive ” ) concerns the progressive implementation of the principle of equal treatment for men and women in matters of social security . Article CARDINAL ) of the Directive prohibits all discrimination on grounds of sex , in particular as concerns the calculation of benefits . Such discrimination can be justified only under LAW , which provides that the Directive is to be without prejudice to the right of member GPE to exclude from its scope the determination of pensionable age for the purposes of granting old - age and retirement pensions and the possible consequences thereof for other benefits . Under LAW CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , “ [ GPE shall periodically examine matters excluded under paragraph CARDINAL in order to ascertain , in the light of social developments in the matter concerned , whether there is justification for maintaining the exclusions concerned ” .

CARDINAL . In case ORG The Queen v. Secretary of ORG , ex parte ORG ( “ ORG ” ) [ DATE ] ORG Reports ( ECR ) I-CARDINAL , the ECJ found that LAW must be interpreted not only as authorising the retention of a statutory pensionable age which differed according to sex , but also forms of discrimination affecting access to certain benefits which were “ necessarily linked ” to the difference in pensionable age . Inequality between men and women , with respect to the contribution periods required in order to obtain a pension of an identical amount , constituted such discrimination where , having regard to the financial equilibrium of the national pension system in the context of which it appeared , it could not be disassociated from the difference in pensionable age .

CARDINAL . NORP In case C-CARDINAL/CARDINAL Secretary of ORG v. PERSON and Others [ DATE ] ECR I-CARDINAL , the ECJ held that the reasoning from the ORG decision extended to benefits linked to differential ORG retirement ages where “ such discrimination is objectively necessary in order to avoid disrupting the complex financial equilibrium of the social security system or to ensure consistency between retirement pension schemes and other benefit schemes ” .

CARDINAL . In the present applicants’ case , C-CARDINAL/CARDINAL Hepple and Others v. Adjudication Officer [ DATE ] ECR I-CARDINAL , the ECJ applied the reasoning of PERSON and Others to find , first , that “ removal of the discrimination at issue ... would have no effect on the financial equilibrium of the social security system of GPE as a whole ” ( § CARDINAL ) . However , it went on to hold that it had been objectively necessary to introduce different age conditions based on sex in order to maintain coherence between the ORG retirement pension scheme and other benefit schemes , since ( § § DATE )

“ ... the principal aim of the successive legislative amendments ... was to discontinue payment of REA – an allowance designed to compensate for an impairment of earning capacity following an accident at work or occupational disease DATE to persons no longer of working age by imposing conditions based on the statutory retirement age .

Thus , as a result of those legislative amendments , there is coherence between ORG , which is designed to compensate for a decrease in earnings , and the old - age pension scheme . It follows that maintenance of the rules at issue in the main proceedings is objectively necessary to preserve such coherence .

That conclusion is not invalidated by the fact that ORG is replaced , when the beneficiary reaches retirement age and stops working , by ORG , the rate of which is PERCENT of ORG , since ORG is designed to compensate for the reduction in pension entitlement resulting from a decrease in earnings following an accident at work or occupational disease .

It follows that discrimination of the kind at issue in the main proceedings is objectively and necessarily linked to the difference between the retirement age for men and that for women , so that it is covered by the derogation for which LAW provides . ”
